5. Verres next appears as legatus to Cn. Dolabella, praetor of Cilicia, Bc. 80-79, a man of kindred spirit with himself—cruel, rapacious, and extortionate. He rehearsed here all the enormities which he was to enact on a larger scale in Sicily, marking his progress through Achaia, even before he reached his province, by the most shameless acts of plunder and profligacy —quaczmque iter fecit, eius modi fuit ut ‘non leyatus popul ί Romami, set ut qzosteclcmn calamitas pervadere videretur (bk. Ι. ξ 144). He proved himself not less faithless to Dolabella than he had been to Carbo; for when the former was impeached for extortion by M. Scaurus in ΒΕ. 78, Verres gave evidence against him, and, stipulating for a pardon for himself, was
